conclusion: Understanding the problem involves two velocity-time graphs for objects A and B moving in the same direction.
The x-axis is time (t), the y-axis is velocity (v), and both curves peak before t1.
The question asks if the difference in displacement between the two objects is continuously increasing from 0 to t1.
A velocity-time graph's area under the curve gives displacement.
Displacement for each object from time 0 to t is the area under its velocity curve from 0 to t.
Both objects move in the same direction with positive velocities.
Curve A is always above curve B up to time t1.
The difference in displacement at any time t is the area under curve A minus the area under curve B.
Since A's velocity is always greater than B's up to t1, the area under curve A is always larger.
The rate of change of displacement difference is d(Δs)/dt = v_A - v_B.
Since v_A > v_B up to t1, d(Δs)/dt > 0, meaning the displacement difference is continuously increasing.
Curve A is always above curve B up to t1, confirming v_A > v_B.
The difference in displacement is continuously increasing during the interval.
A consistently having a higher velocity means A pulls away from B, increasing displacement difference.
If both objects start from the same point, the position difference is the displacement difference.
Given v_A > v_B, the rate of change of Δs(t) is positive, so Δs(t) keeps increasing.
Even if the velocity difference decreases, as long as v_A > v_B, the displacement difference increases.
If acceleration is positive but decreasing, velocity still increases.
As long as v_A > v_B, the displacement difference keeps increasing.
The integral of (v_A - v_B) dt from 0 to t1 is positive, so the displacement difference increases.
d(Δs)/dt > 0 for all t in [0, t1] means Δs(t) is monotonically increasing.
